title: April 2016 Paper 2 - Licensure Exam
description: NCK Community Health Nurse (Basic) Licensure Examination Paper Two from April 2016. Covers MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay questions converted for interactive practice.

questions.question: The deep muscles of the pelvis floor include:-
questions.explanation: The deep muscle layer (pelvic diaphragm) consists mainly of the Levator Ani muscles (Pubococcygeus, Iliococcygeus) and the Coccygeus (Ischiococcygeus). Bulbo-cavernosus and Ischiocavernosus are superficial muscles.
questions.hint: Look for muscles ending in -coccygeus; -cavernosus muscles are superficial.

questions.question: The hormone which is responsible for the growth of the myometrium during pregnancy is:-
questions.explanation: Oestrogen causes hypertrophy (increase in size) and hyperplasia (increase in number) of the myometrial muscle fibers, causing the uterus to grow. Progesterone relaxes the smooth muscle.
questions.hint: This hormone is the primary 'growth' hormone of the reproductive system.

questions.question: Minor disorders of pregnancy include:-

options.text: Nausea and vomiting, heartburn, ptyalism, backache.
Nausea and vomiting, heart burn, ptyalism, hyperemesis gravidarum.
Nausea and vomiting, heart burn, backache, vaginal bleeding.
Heart burn, ptyalism, backache, reduced foetal movements.

questions.explanation: Nausea, heartburn, ptyalism (excess saliva), and backache are common physiological discomforts. Hyperemesis, vaginal bleeding, and reduced fetal movements are complications/danger signs.
questions.hint: Select the list that contains ONLY normal discomforts, no danger signs.

questions.question: The specific aims of performing an abdominal examination on a pregnant woman include:-

options.text: To observe signs of pregnancy, assess fetal size and growth, assess fetal health.
To observe signs of pregnancy, assess fetal size and growth, assess maternal well being.
To diagnose the location of fetal parts, assess fetal health, assess maternal well being.
To diagnose the location of fetal parts, assess fetal size and growth, assess maternal pulse rate.

questions.explanation: The key objectives of abdominal palpation are assessing fetal size/growth (fundal height), fetal lie/presentation (location), and fetal well-being (FHR). Maternal well-being is not the primary aim of abdominal palpation specifically.
questions.hint: Focus on what you feel about the fetus during the exam.

questions.question: The commonest cause of pyelonephritis in pregnancy is:-
questions.explanation: E. coli is responsible for 70-80% of urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis in pregnancy due to the anatomical proximity of the urethra to the rectum.
questions.hint: This organism is common in the bowel.

questions.question: During labour, the level of the presenting part is estimated in relation to the maternal ischial spines in order to:-

options.text: Assess the state of the cervix.
Assess the descent of the fetus in labour.
Assess the descent of the head.

questions.explanation: Station is the relationship of the presenting part to the ischial spines, used to measure descent. Option C is the most accurate general description.
questions.hint: This measurement (Station) tells you how far down the baby has moved.

questions.question: At the beginning of third stage of labour, the fundal height is:-

options.text: 2 – 5 below the umbilicus and 10 cm above the symphysis pubis.
2 – 5 cm below the umbilicus and 15 cm above the symphysis pubis.
1.5 cm above the umbilicus and 19 cm above the symphysis pubis.
1.5 cm below the umbilicus and 19 cm above the symphysis pubis.

questions.explanation: Immediately after the baby is born, the uterus retracts to a level just below the umbilicus (roughly 20 weeks size/19-20cm above symphysis).
questions.hint: It drops down significantly from the xiphisternum to near the umbilicus.

questions.question: The third degree perineal tear involves:-

options.text: The fourchette and superficial perineal muscles.
The fourchette and the anal sphincter.
The fourchette, superficial perineal muscles and the anal sphincter.
The fourchette and the rectal mucosa.

questions.explanation: 3rd degree tears involve the skin, muscles, AND the anal sphincter. 4th degree involves the rectal mucosa.
questions.hint: It goes deeper than muscles but stops before the rectal lining.

questions.question: The immediate action a midwife takes on diagnosing cord presentation is to:-

options.text: Allow the woman to continue in labour.
Put the woman in knee chest position.

questions.explanation: Cord presentation (membranes intact) risks prolapse if membranes rupture. Priority is to relieve pressure by positioning (knee-chest/Trendelenburg) and prepare for CS. Never rupture membranes.
questions.hint: Use gravity to keep the baby's head off the cord.

questions.question: The indications for emergency caesarean section include:-
questions.explanation: Cord prolapse and uterine rupture are immediate life-threatening emergencies requiring the fastest possible delivery.
questions.hint: Which pair represents immediate catastrophes?

questions.question: Which of the following statements about newborn assessment is TRUE?

options.text: A newborn whose birth weight is below 2.5kgs is defined as a premature baby.
A normal full term baby weighs approx 3.5kg, length 50cm, head circumference 34-35cm.
Prematurity is defined by weight, not gestation.

questions.explanation: Statement (a) is False: <2.5kg is Low Birth Weight, not necessarily premature. Statement (b) is True: These are standard term measurements.
questions.hint: Distinguish between 'Premature' (time) and 'Small' (weight).

questions.question: The management of physiological jaundice in a term baby includes:-

options.text: Early feeding and exposure to sunlight.

questions.explanation: Early and frequent feeding helps excrete bilirubin via stool. Sunlight (heliotherapy) was traditionally used and is often cited in older exams/texts, though frequent feeding is the most critical physiological intervention.
questions.hint: Think about how bilirubin leaves the body.

questions.question: A baby whose weight is 1450 gms should be fed via:-
questions.explanation: Infants <1500g typically lack a coordinated suck-swallow-breathe reflex. NGT feeding is required until they mature enough for cup or breast feeding.
questions.hint: Very small babies cannot swallow safely yet.

questions.question: The causes of intra-uterine growth retardation (IUGR) include:-
questions.explanation: Pre-eclampsia causes placental insufficiency leading to IUGR. Severe chronic infections (like pneumonia) can also cause hypoxia/IUGR. (Note: Diabetes typically causes macrosomia unless vasculopathy is present).
questions.hint: Conditions that restrict blood flow to the placenta or cause maternal hypoxia.

questions.question: In normal puerperium, the term given to the vaginal discharge during the next 5 – 9 days is:-
questions.explanation: Lochia Rubra (Red): Days 1-4. Lochia Serosa (Pink/Brown): Days 5-9. Lochia Alba (White): Days 10+.
questions.hint: Rubra is red, Alba is white, Serosa is in between.

questions.question: The common causative organisms of puerperal infection include:-
questions.explanation: Beta-hemolytic streptococcus (Group A Strep) is the classic and most dangerous cause. Clostridium Welchii is a serious anaerobic cause.
questions.hint: Streptococcus is a major culprit.

questions.question: The role of the midwife in the management of deep venous thrombosis includes:-

options.text: Administering appropriate anticoagulant, mobilizing the affected limb.
Administering appropriate anticoagulant, restricting mobilization of affected limb.
Administering antibiotics, restricting mobilization of affected limb.

questions.explanation: Anticoagulants are the treatment. In the acute phase, restricting mobilization was traditionally taught to prevent clot detachment (embolism), though modern guidelines vary, for exams 'rest' is often the expected answer alongside anticoagulation.
questions.hint: Stop the clot from growing (drugs) and moving (rest).

questions.question: A postnatal mother who does not breastfeed and seeks to use contraception immediately should be advised to use:-

options.text: Progesterone only oral pill, intrauterine copper device.

questions.explanation: Since she is NOT breastfeeding, estrogen methods (Combined Pill) are safe to use (after immediate postpartum VTE risk period). Implants are also safe. Lactational amenorrhea is impossible if not breastfeeding.
questions.hint: If not breastfeeding, she doesn't need to avoid estrogen for milk supply reasons.

questions.question: The main causes of perinatal deaths include:-
questions.explanation: Intrauterine hypoxia (asphyxia) and birth trauma (intracranial injury) are major direct causes of perinatal mortality.
questions.hint: Think about direct causes of death during labor and birth.

questions.question: The signs and symptoms of puerperal psychosis include:-

options.text: Mother refuses to feed, loses interest on baby.
Mother develops suicidal tendencies, likes her baby.
Mother develops suicidal tendencies, feeds well.

questions.explanation: Puerperal psychosis involves severe detachment, hallucinations, and confusion. Losing interest in or rejecting the baby is a hallmark sign of this severe mental illness.
questions.hint: This is a severe detachment from reality and the infant.

questions.question: When drawing a diagram of the female gynaecoid pelvis, which labels should be included? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Key landmarks of the pelvic brim include the Sacral Promontory, Sacral Alae, Sacroiliac Joints, Iliopectineal Line, Iliopectineal Eminence, Superior Pubic Ramus, and Symphysis Pubis.
questions.hint: Focus on the landmarks forming the pelvic inlet (brim).

questions.question: What are the functions of the pelvic floor muscles? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Maintain continence of urine and faeces

questions.explanation: The pelvic floor provides Support (organs), Control (sphincters/continence), and Reproductive function (stretch during birth).
questions.hint: They hold things up and keep things in.

questions.question: Select the specific aims of Antenatal Care (ANC): (Select all that apply)

options.text: Monitor progress of pregnancy and fetal well-being
Prepare mother for labor and parenthood

questions.explanation: ANC aims to monitor health, detect problems, prepare for birth, and educate. It cannot guarantee a specific labor outcome like 'pain-free'.
questions.hint: Think about prevention, detection, and education.

questions.question: What are the functions of a mature placenta? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The placenta acts as the fetal lungs (respiration), gut (nutrition), kidney (excretion), and endocrine gland.
questions.hint: It does everything the baby's organs can't do yet.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of obstructed labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Obstruction presents with stalled progress despite strong contractions, leading to maternal distress, Bandl's ring (impending rupture), fetal distress, and severe moulding/caput.
questions.hint: Look for signs that the baby is stuck and the mother/uterus is exhausted.

questions.question: What are the roles of the midwife in the immediate care of the newborn? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Immediate care involves Airway, Warmth, Assessment (Apgar), Cord care, and ID. Vaccination usually happens after stabilization.
questions.hint: Prioritize survival (breathing, warmth) and safety (ID).

questions.question: Which of the following are possible sources of umbilical cord infection? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Application of cow dung or ash to stump
Leaving the cord stump dry and exposed to air

questions.explanation: Infection comes from unsterile tools, hands, dirty dressings/diapers, or harmful traditional applications. Dry care is protective.
questions.hint: Anything dirty touching the cord causes infection.

questions.question: What are the benefits of PMTCT (Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission) of HIV? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Improved maternal health via early ART
Encourages partner testing and family health

questions.explanation: PMTCT reduces transmission to the baby, improves mother's health through treatment, and promotes family testing. It is not a cure.
questions.hint: It protects the baby and helps the mother live longer.

questions.question: Differentiate between True and False Labour:

richContent.content:
FeatureTrue LabourFalse Labour
ContractionsRegular, increase in intensityIrregular, erratic
CervixProgressive dilatationNo change
SedationNot stopped by sedationRelieved by sedation

questions.explanation: True labour leads to cervical change and has regular, intensifying contractions. False labour does not change the cervix and is often relieved by sedation/rest.
questions.hint: The main difference is what happens to the cervix.

questions.question: Which physiological changes occur during the first stage of labour? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Formation of upper and lower uterine segments
Effacement and dilatation of the cervix

questions.explanation: First stage involves uterine action (polarity, fundal dominance) preparing the cervix (effacement/dilation). Placental expulsion is 3rd stage.
questions.hint: Everything that happens before the baby is pushed out.

questions.question: What are common complications of labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Major complications include obstruction, hemorrhage, cord accidents, and rupture. Morning sickness is a pregnancy symptom.
questions.hint: Think of life-threatening events during birth.

questions.question: How is Low Birth Weight (LBW) defined?

options.text: Birth weight less than 2500g regardless of gestation.

questions.explanation: LBW is strictly a weight definition (<2.5kg). Preterm is a time definition. SGA is a percentile definition.
questions.hint: It's purely about the scale reading.

questions.question: Match the condition with its characteristics:

pairs.right: Born <37 weeks, organ immaturity, lanugo present
Weight <10th percentile, looks starved, loose skin

questions.explanation: Preterm babies are immature. SFD babies are malnourished/growth restricted.
questions.hint: One is 'too early', the other is 'too small'.

questions.question: What is included in the management of a 1400g (VLBW) baby in the first 72 hours? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: VLBW babies need warmth (incubator), specialized feeding (NGT), and monitoring. Bathing causes hypothermia and is delayed.
questions.hint: Keep them warm, fed, and monitored. Don't wash them yet.

questions.question: Which of the following are complications of preterm babies? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Preterms face risks from organ immaturity: lungs (RDS), liver (Jaundice), temp control (Hypothermia), and metabolism (Hypoglycemia).
questions.hint: Organs aren't ready yet: lungs, liver, and fat stores are lacking.
